title: How can an SBA collector come after me aggressively when the only income/asset I reported/had was from the business that failed?
question: Hi, I was a 50% owner of a business, for 10 years with a partner back in 2017. At one point in Sept of 2017, my BP decided she no longer wanted to be in business and signed off. Well, at that point I choose to continue with business: however, I didn't realize my BP had taken a huge amount of money from the business account which would've caused the business to crumble within a mo. or two. So i was recommended to take out a small business loan, & I did in Dec of 2017. At the time I wasn't aware the business vendorization was only valid if neither of us resigned & when she signed off the business & submitted a letter of resignation, the agency contract was void & the business closed. I had already pulled the loan & used the money to buy inventory. When I applied for the loan I was very clear, the only asset & income I had/received was from the business, I'm applying for the loan on. Since the SBA defaulted, the collection agency tells me I have to pay the full $9000 by April 1, 2019, or make an agreement to pay $1000 for nine mos. I am on SSDI now I don't even get $1000 per mo, now they're suing me to levy my accts/garnishing me & reporting bad on my credit report. HELP ME! Plz
answers:
From what you describe as very limited assets, it seems unlikely that any efforts by the SBA to collect the subject debt from you would be successful. Your SS income is automatically exempt and cannot be intercepted by the SBA. In bankruptcy, certain debts owed to the government are non-dischargable, however, SBA loans can be discharged.

Remember, BK is more than checking boxes on forms you find online. Find/consult/hire a lawyer using the Avvo feature "Find a Lawyer". Make a list of 4-5 having many 5 star reviews from satisfied clients. If you don't get a prompt call back from one, go on to the next on your list. Some offer a free consultation by phone or in person.

Before you hire a lawyer to file for bankruptcy IMO you should hire a DIFFERENT lawyer experienced in working out terrible SBA loan situations like this. If the experienced business lawyer you hire is good enough, they should be able to convince the SBA to leave you alone; or if that is not possible, then to put you on a very long-term payoff plan--a long term plan with low payments that will outlive you. Do NOT procrastinate; hire a business lawyer ASAP.
Not sure, maybe a BK attorney can help...
